Oxidative stress-mediated selective antimicrobial ability of nanoVO2 against Gram-positive bacteria for environmental and biomedical applications
Jinhua Li,a, b Huaijuan Zhou,a, b Jiaxing Wang,c Donghui Wang,a,b Ruxiang Shen,a Xianlong Zhang,c Ping Jina, d, * and Xuanyong Liua, *
Vanadium dioxide (VO2) is a unique thermochromic material contributed by its semiconductor-metal transition, holding
great promise for energy-saving intelligent windows. Herein, pure nano-VO2 from discrete nanoparticles to continuous films
were successfully deposited on quartz glass by controlling sputter parameters. It further demonstrated that, for Gram-
positive S. aureus and S. epidermidis, the nano-VO2 could effectively disrupt bacteria morphology and membrane integrity,
and eventually cause death. By contrast, the nano-VO2 did not exert significant toxicity on Gram-negative E. coli and P.
aeruginosa. To our knowledge, this is the first time to report on a selective antimicrobial effect of nano-VO2 materials on
Gram-positive bacteria. Based on the experimental results, a plausible mechanism was proposed for the antimicrobial
selectivity, which might originate from the different sensitivity of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria to intracellular
reactive oxygen species (ROS) level. Elevated intracellular ROS level exceed the threshold that bacteria can self-regulate to
maintain cellular redox homeostasis and thus cause oxidative stress, which can be alleviated by elaborate intervention of
glutathione (GSH) antioxidant. In addition, nano-VO2 did not produce significant cytotoxicity (hemolysis) against human
erythrocytes within 12 h. Meanwhile, potential cytotoxicity against HIBEpiC revealed a time and dose dependent manner
that might be controlled and balanced by elaborate design. The finding in the present work may contribute to understanding
the antimicrobial behaviors of nano-VO2 and expanding the new applications of VO2-based nanomaterials in environmental
and biomedical fields.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Smart windows, capable of regulating solar/heat transmittance for energy efficiency and comfort, have the potential to moderate the energy consumptions of buildings, which is almost the equivalent of 30~40% of the primary energy used in the worldwide. Vanadium dioxide (VO2) has been regarded as the promising material for thermochromic intelligent windows owing to its unique semiconductor-metal transition (SMT) temperature near room temperature. During the cold days when the extraventricular temperature is below the SMT temperature, VO2 has a monoclinic structure (P21/c) and is infrared-transparent to keep the warmth of inside house and maintains visible transmittance. On the contrary, during hot days, VO2 transforms to high-temperature rutile structure (P42/mnm) which is infrared-reflective to ensure that less infrared light is passed into the house.1 On the one hand, when VO2 is utilized as surface coating of windows in buildings or cars, it is exposed to surrounding environment and inevitably touched by human bodies,
especially by hands. On the other hand, detrimental environmental microbes exist everywhere around, such as in air, water, food and so forth.2 In this case, the pathogens adhering on surface will cause potential health threats to individuals and public. In this context, if VO2-based smart window has the ability to kill some bacteria, it will be of great significance and necessity for VO2 in practical application.
From the perspective of biomedical purpose, nowadays, antibiotic-resistant bacteria create huge needs for breakthrough in treating infectious diseases.3-5 The situation of antimicrobial resistance is so serious. For example, vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) has an intrinsic resistance to some commonly used antibiotics, as well as developing resistance to all currently available antibiotics.5 Methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) accounts for more than 40% of S. aureus strains in hospitals,4 and vancomycinresistant S. aureus (VRSA) is a global and daunting medical challenge because vancomycin is the most effective treatment for S. aureus infection.6-7 Meanwhile, multi-drug resistance has also been increasing among Gram-negative bacteria.5, 8 In the context of research and clinical applications, it is very impending today to develop novel and effective antimicrobial drugs. Nanomaterialbased antimicrobial agents provide a new paradigm for overcoming antibiotics-resistant pathogens, which has been explored as a promising alternative to current antibiotics-based methods.9-12 Meanwhile, they also hold great promise for applications in environmental system where biofouling is a major cause of elevated operation costs in marine transport, membrane-based water treatment and heat exchangers.13-15 Some engineered oxide nanoparticles have shown excellent antimicrobial property, such as a. That determines the toxicity of vanadium is its physicochemical states, especially its solubility and valence state.19-20 Vanadium owns six oxidation states, with trivalence(+3), tetravalence(+4), and pentavalence(+5) as the most common forms in nature. The increase in oxidation state will elevate the toxicity of vanadium.21-22 On the one hand, among various subcellular organelle, mitochondrion, the powerhouse of the cell, is a momentous target for vanadium accumulation and cytotoxicity in biological systems.23-25 On the other hand, based on the Endosymbiotic theory (Symbiogenesis), eukaryote mitochondria are an analogue of prokaryote bacteria. In this context, it is expected that vanadium may also impose toxic effect on bacteria just as it does on mitochondria, in other words, have antimicrobial potential.
In fact, some vanadium coordination organic compounds have shown the potential for treating epidemic diseases caused by parasites.26-28 Vanadium-substituted polyoxidotungstate, decomposing into active species vanadate(+5) and tungstate(+4) at physiological conditions, also shows in vitro antiviral activity against viruses causing influenza and Dengue fever, human immune deficiency virus (HIV-1) and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).29-30 More excitingly, V(+5) complex [VO2(tsc)] and its V(+4) precursor [VO(acac)tsc] (tsc, thiosemicarbazone; acac, acetylacetonate) show inhibiting effect on tuberculosis pathogens, Mycobacterium tuberculosis.31 All these signs point out that it is quite worth trying to explore the antimicrobial potential of nano-VO2.
We deduce that VO2 may possess the capacity of killing bacteria. If so, it will be of great significance for both environmental and biomedical applications. To explore the conjecture above, the antibacterial potentials of nano-VO2 (from particle to film) on typical representatives of Gram-positive bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis) and Gram-negative bacteria (Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) were investigated in this work. Human erythrocytes and intrahepatic biliary epithelial cells were used to evaluate the potential cytotoxicity. The prepared nano-VO2 showed a selective antimicrobial effect on the Grampositive bacteria and a plausible mechanism behind the antibacterial selectivity was proposed from the perspective of difference in susceptibility to intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) level. To our knowledge, this is the first time to report on the selective antimicrobial property of nano-VO2, and the finding may be conducive to understanding the antibacterial behaviors of nano-VO2 and designing the new applications of VO2-based nanomaterials for environmental and biomedical purposes.

sections.heading: 2.1 VO2 deposition and sample preparation
sections.text:
The high quality VO2 from discrete nanoparticles to continuous films were prepared by magnetron sputtering apparatus (ULVAC Corp.,
Model ACS-4000-C4) with metal vanadium target. Fused quartz was
used as the substrate for VO2 deposition. The process parameters for VO2 deposition can be found in our previous work.32-33 To obtain the VO2 samples from discrete nanoparticles to continuous films, VO2 was deposited on quartz substrate within 10 min, followed by
vacuum annealing treatment at 450 ºC. For simplicity, the VO2 samples from discrete nanoparticles to continuous films on quartz
deposited for 2 min, 4 min, 6 min and 8 min were denoted as VO-1,
VO-2, VO-3 and VO-4, respectively. Meanwhile, the quartz glass
acted as the control group (VO-0).

sections.heading: 2.2. Sample surface characterization
sections.text: A field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM; HITACHI S-4800, Japan) was used to examine the surface morphology of samples VO-0, VO-1, VO-2, VO-3 and VO-4. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PHI 5802, Physical Electronics Inc, Eden Prairie, MN) with an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) source was used to investigate the surface chemical components and element chemical states of samples VO-1, VO-2, VO-3 and VO-4.

sections.text: The release profiles of vanadium ions from the surfaces of samples VO-0, VO-1, VO-2, VO-3 and VO-4 in agar-free Trypticase Soy Broth (TSB) medium, agar-free Luria-Bertani (LB) medium and phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH 6.8/7.4, adjusted by HCl solution) were measured by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Varian Liberty 150, US). sections.heading: 2.6. Hydrogen peroxide study
sections.text:
To investigate the behavior responses of Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus and S. epidermidis) and Gram-negative bacteria (E. coli and P. aeruginosa) toward hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the H2O2 concentration dependent microbial viability was studied by AlamarBlue assay to plot the growth-inhibitory curves of these microbes in H2O2-containing medium. And the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) values were obtained by GraphPad Prism 5 statistical software package. In brief, before use, H2O2 (AR, 30%) solution was freshly diluted in PBS to 10 M stock solution, filtration sterilized, and then diluted in PBS to prepare working solution with concentrations ranging from 10 M to 0. After that, the bacterial solution (107 CFU/ml) were inoculated into 96-well plate pre-supplemented with the above working solution. After 24 h of culture, the AlamarBlue assay was performed to measure the bacterial viability as above. The test was repeated five times independently under the same experimental conditions, strictly following the manufacturer's instructions. The final IC50 values were expressed as means ± standard deviation. 2.7. Intracellular ROS assay
Intracellular ROS levels in the bacterial cells were determined by Intracellular ROS Assay Kit (Beyotime, China) following the manufacturer’s instruction.34 In this assay, 2’,7’- dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) can pass through bacterial membrane and be deacetylated by intracellular esterases into non-fluorescent dichlorofluorescin (DCFH) to stay in bacteria, which can be oxidized into highly fluorescent 2’,7’- dichlorofluorescein (DCF) by intracellular ROS.35 After 24 h of culture as above, bacteria were thoroughly detached from sample surface by vigorously vibrating in vortex mixer. Aliquots of 100 μl were taken from each specimen to determine the number of bacteria, and remanent bacterial suspensions were collected into 96-well flatbottom black plate to measure the relative fluorescent intensity (RFI) of intracellular ROS. Briefly, DCFH-DA (10 μM) was added into the above bacterial suspensions in 96-well black plate, followed by 20 min of incubation at 37 ºC. Then the RFI was detected on Cytation 5 Cell Imaging Multi-Mode Reader (BioTek, US) at excitation wavelength λex=485 nm and emission wavelength λem=535 nm. sections.heading: 2.8. Antioxidant incubation study
sections.text: To explore the potential role of oxidative stress in nano-VO2 induced bacterial inactivation, we co-incubated the Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus and S. epidermidis) with 10 mM glutathione (reduced form, GSH), the major endogenous antioxidant, to alleviate/remove the contribution of oxidative stress in the bacterial response to the nano-VO2 exposure. This strategy has been previously revealed to effectively attenuate the oxidative stress induced by cellular pro-oxidants.37-38 The bacterial viability and intracellular ROS level were evaluated by using the methods as described above. At the same time, the LIVE/DEAD® BacLight™ Kit (L13152, Molecular Probes) was used to stain the co-incubated bacteria to visualize their bacterial viability and membrane integrity (Please see details in Section 2.5).

sections.heading: 2.9. CFU counting assay
sections.text:
To further corroborate the above AlamarBlue assay results, the CFU counting assay was carried out on the Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus and S. epidermidis) with/without GSH co-incubation. After sterilizing the samples in ethanol solution (75 v/v%) and drying them on super clean bench, a droplet of bacterial solution (60 μl, 107 CFU/ml) with/without 10 mM GSH was inoculated onto each sample surface (1×1 cm2) in a 24-well plate, followed by another 24 h of incubation at 37 ºC in the dark. Afterwards, the CFU counting assay was conducted. In brief, each sample with bacterial solution was gently transferred into 1 ml of sterile PBS, followed by 10 min of ultrasonic vibration (150 W, B3500S-MT, Branson Ultrasonics Co., Shanghai, China) and 1 min of rapid vortex mixing (Vortex Genie 2, Scientific Industries, Bohemia, NY, USA) to dissociate the bacteria thoroughly. The bacterial suspension was then taken out and the viable counts of bacteria were measured by serial dilution and spread-plate method.39 The numbers of CFU on the sheep blood agar (SBA) were counted according to the National Standard of China GB/T 4789.2 protocol. sections.heading: 2.10. Hemolysis assay
sections.text:
Hemolysis assay was performed according to a modified method described elsewhere.40 Our experimental study was approved by Shanghai Jiao Tong University Affiliated Sixth People’s Hospital Ethics Committee (Ethical code, 2014-63). Human venous blood from healthy young volunteers was collected in tubes containing 10 μl of heparin. 10 ml of whole blood was centrifuged at 1200×g for 5 min, then the supernatant and buffy coat were gently removed and discarded. The red blood cells (RBC) were gently washed thrice with sterile PBS buffer solution (pH 7.4, Gibco). Subsequently, the RBC were resuspended in PBS solution at 2% hematocrit. After that, the RBC suspension was incubated with VO-0, VO-1, VO-2, VO-3, VO-4 (n = 3) and aseptic distilled water (positive control). Assay was incubated at 37 °C in an incubator for 15 min, 30 min, 60 min, 4 h and 12 h. At the end of each time period, one aliquot was withdrawn and intact RBC were removed by centrifugation at 1200×g for 5 min at 4 °C. The supernatants were collected and the hemolysis was analyzed by measuring the absorbance of hemoglobin at 540 nm. All measurements were taken in triplicate. sections.heading: 2.11. Cell viability assessment
sections.text:
To estimate the cytotoxicity of nano-VO2, the human intrahepatic biliary epithelial cells (HIBEpiC) were cultured on samples VO-0, VO-1, VO-2, VO-3 and VO-4. Briefly, HIBEpiC were seeded on these samples for 1, 4 and 7 d of culture in 24-well plate (density 5×104 cells/well, five samples per group) in Epithelial Cell Medium (EpiCM, ScienCell), supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% P/S. At the end of each culture period, the cellular medium was removed and AlamarBlue assay was performed to measure the cell proliferation and viability (Please see details in Section 2.5).
With the help of Live/Dead Cell Staining Kit (BioVision, US), CLSM was utilized to visualize the live and dead HIBEpiC. Briefly, HIBEpiC were firstly seeded on samples VO-0, VO-1, VO-2, VO-3 and VO-4 in 24-well plate (5×104 cells/well) for 4 d of culture. Then they were stained with the mixed solution of 5 μM PI (red fluorescent dye for dead cells) and 2 μM calcein-AM (green fluorescent dye for live cells) with 100 μl per well, followed by subsequent incubation for 15 min at 37 °C before CLSM observation.

sections.heading: 2.12. Statistical analysis
sections.text:
Statistically significant differences (P) between various groups were measured using one-way analysis of variance and Tukey’s multiple comparison tests on a GraphPad Prism 5 statistical software package. All the data were expressed as means ± standard deviation (SD). A value of P<0.05 was considered to be statistically significant and denoted as “*”, P<0.01 was “**”, and P<0.001 was “***”.

For sample VO-1 (2 min), discrete VO2 nanoparticles were produced on quartz glass, as shown in Figure 1a (indicated by green arrow). The surface speciation and charge formation were also analysed for all specimens. The isoelectric point of surface (IEPS) is the pH of aqueous solution when total surface charge density is zero. A substrate surface is positively (negatively) charged when pH is lower (higher) than its IEPS. As shown in Figure 2d, for VO-0 (quartz), at IEPS (~3.7), the total charge density of the hydrated surface (SiO2+H2O=H2SiO3) was zero,41 and departure of pH from the IEPS altered the surface charge accordingly (H2SiO3+OH-→HSiO3-+H2O， pH ＞ 3.7 ； H2SiO3+H+→H3SiO3+ ， pH ＜ 3.7). For nano-VO2, at prevalent oxic conditions, intermediate state VO2 has a tendency to oxidize to V2O5 (4VO2+O2→2V2O5), and the total charge density of the hydrated surface (V2O5+3H2O=2H3VO4) at IEPS (<3) is zero.42 Here, above IEPS, a negatively charged surface was formed on nano-VO2 accordingly. For further analysis, the pKa values for vanadate were essential (H3VO4+H2O↔H2VO4-+H3O+ ， pKa=3.5 ； H2VO4+H2O↔HVO42-+H3O+ ， pKa=7.8 ； HVO42-+OH-↔VO43-+H2O ， pKa=12.5).43 As a result, negatively charged surface were formed on nanoVO2 in a wide pH range, as indicated in Figure 2d. From this figure, the difference and change in surface zeta potentials of quartz and nano-VO2 exactly reflected the evolution of the latter from discrete nanoparticles to continuous film. 3.2. Figure 3 shows the release profiles of vanadium ions in different solutions within 14 d of immersion. From this figure, it can be seen that vanadium ions were slowly released from the surfaces of various VO2 samples in a time and dose dependent manner. On the other hand, the corresponding release rates and release amounts of vanadium ions showed no significant difference among various solutions, especially for agar-free TSB (Figure 3a) and agar-free LB (Figure 3b). The release of vanadium ions might correlate with its intracellular toxicity.44

sections.heading: 3.3. Selective antibacterial property

sections.heading: 3.4. Plausible antibacterial mechanism

Vanadium toxicity ascends as the oxidation state increases.21-22 Our recent work showed that +5 valent vanadate (H2VO4−) anions were released from surface when immersing VO2 in PBS.45 The soluble H2VO4− are the main species at physiological pH since the pentavalent oxidation state is the most stable form among various oxidation states.25, 46

On the contrary, the proliferation of S. aureus and S. epidermidis was significantly reduced on nano-VO2, as shown in Figure 7e-f. Consistent with the SEM and staining results, it also demonstrated the nano-VO2 had selective antibacterial property against the tested Gram-positive bacteria. Meanwhile, the intracellular ROS level of S. aureus and S. epidermidis showed several-fold increase than that on quartz. Upon the evolution of nano-VO2 from particle to film, the intracellular ROS level of S. aureus and S. epidermidis also indicated rhythmic varying pattern. To further confirm the role of oxidative stress in nano-VO2 induced bacterial inactivation, we coincubated Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus and S. epidermidis) with 10 mM GSH to eliminate the contribution of oxidative stress in the bacterial response to nanoVO2 exposure. As for S. epidermidis, the antibacterial effect of nano-VO2 was entirely deactivated and the bacterial viability was significantly increased to the level of control (Figure 7k). sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this work, pure VO2 from discrete nanoparticles to continuous films were successfully deposited on quartz glass by optimizing sputter parameters. The nano-VO2 could effectively reduce the bacterial viability of Gram-positive S. aureus and S. epidermidis, disrupt bacterial morphology and membrane integrity, induce oxidative stress and ultimately cause bacterial death. On the contrary, Gram-negative E. coli and P. aeruginosa did not exhibit the similar responses to nano-VO2, without significant toxic effects being observed. Therefore, to the best of our knowledge, a selective antibacterial property of VO2-based nanomaterials against Grampositive bacteria was demonstrated here for the first time. Based on experimental results, the plausible mechanism behind the antibacterial selectivity might result from the difference in sensitivity of Gram-positive bacteria and Gram-negative bacteria to intracellular ROS level. Excessive ROS production induced by nanoVO2 could cause oxidative stress and bacterial inactivation. Besides, the nano-VO2 did not cause significant cytotoxicity (hemolysis) against human erythrocytes within 12 h. Meanwhile, the potential cytotoxicity against HIBEpiC showed a time and dose dependent manner that might be controlled and balanced by elaborate design. The present finding in this work may be conducive to understanding the antibacterial actions of nano-VO2 and expanding the new applications of VO2-based nanomaterials in environmental and biomedical fields.
